column5: Gini coefficient
column7: The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

column2: Income share of the top 10% (Disposable, equivalized)
column5: Top 10% share
column7: This is the income of the richest 10% as a share of total income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

column2: Income share of the bottom 50% (Disposable, equivalized)
column5: Bottom 50% share
column7: This is the income of the poorest 50% as a share of total income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

P90 and P10 are the levels of income below which 90% and 10% of the population live, respectively. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

The P90/P50 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the richest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that someone just falling in the richest tenth of the population has twice the median income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

The P50/P10 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the poorest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that the median income is two times higher than that of someone just falling in the poorest tenth of the population. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

column5: Palma ratio
column7: The Palma ratio is the share of total income of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

column2: Relative poverty: Share of people below 50% of the median income (Disposable, equivalized)
column5: Share in relative poverty (< 50% of the median)
column7: Relative poverty is measured in terms of a poverty line that rises and falls over time with average incomes – in this case set at 50% of the median income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

The P90/P50 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the richest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that someone just falling in the richest tenth of the population has twice the median income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

column5: Gini coefficient
column7: The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the wealth distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

column5: Top 10% share
column7: This is the wealth of the richest 10% as a share of total wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

column5: Top 1% share
column7: This is the wealth of the richest 1% as a share of total wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

column5: Top 0.1% share
column7: This is the wealth of the richest 0.1% as a share of total wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

column5: Top 0.01% share
column7: This is the wealth of the richest 0.01% as a share of total wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

column5: Top 0.001% share
column7: This is the wealth of the richest 0.001% as a share of total wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

P90 and P10 are the levels of wealth below which 90% and 10% of the population live, respectively. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

The P90/P50 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the richest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that someone just falling in the richest tenth of the population has twice the median wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

The P50/P10 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the poorest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that the median wealth is two times higher than that of someone just falling in the poorest tenth of the population. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

column5: Palma ratio
column7: The Palma ratio is the share of total wealth of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

column5:
The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Income share of the bottom 50% (Disposable household income, equivalized)

column5:
P90 is the the level of income below which 90% of the population lives. P10 is the level of income below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column5:
P90 is the the level of income above which 10% of the population lives. P50 is the median – the level of income below which 50% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the top half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone in the middle of the distribution would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column5:
P50 is the median – the level of income below which 50% of the population lives. P10 is the the level of income below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the bottom half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be reach the median.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.

This is net national wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.
